etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in Gerard Manley Hopkins (1844–1889), poet. Irregularly from re- + wind + -ed

definitions: G. M. Hopkins's word for: (apparently) newly wound, rewound.

notes.text: Hopkins comments on the extended passage in which the word is used in a letter of 1882 to Robert Bridges (1955 ed., p. 164).
